result.execSummary:
The defendant Kevin J. Husnick was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take >$500 - $5000) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Portage County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: *Pay restitution to Walmart in Plover - joint/several

*Pay costs
*Pay DNA Surcharge 
*If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

*Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent.
*Write letter of apology to Walmart in Plover and provide to agent 
*Not to be on the premises of Walmart in Plover 
*Provide true and accurate information to the District Attorney's Office regarding all other individual(s) involved in this theft
*Provide DNA sample
*Bond monies to be applied to restitution first and then costs

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

superMiscConds.notes: Defendant is required to authorize the department to collect funds from the defendant's wages and from other moneys held in the defendant's prisoner's account to be used for payment of obligations in reasonable amounts as determined by DOC. If any fines, costs, surcharges, & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

from DOC w/Judge notes
Transcript for Sentencing After Revocation Hearing held on May 31, 2018

Defendant Kevin J. Husnick in court with attorney Erik John Mcfarland. Defendant Kevin J. Husnick in custody. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
10:34 a.m.  Court calls the case.  

Court and both counsel have received the Revocation Order and Warrant packet.  Neither party has any corrections. 
Atty Cousins makes sentencing arguments to the Court.  Requests 1 year prison with 1 year extended supervision concurrent with other cases.  46 days credit.   Defendant is currently serving a prison sentence.  There is a case pending that likely will result in further confinement.  
Atty McFarland makes sentencing arguments to the court.  Believes a concurrent sentence is appropriate and asks the court to find him eligible for programming.  He has not been able to get his substance abuse under control.  He came up with 48 days credit. 
Atty Cousins agrees with the 48 days credit. 
Court questions if the defendant has been sentenced in Langlade County. 
Atty McFarland responds.  He has been sentence in Marinette county.  The Langladge county case is set for a status conference sometime in June. He is serving the Marinette and the imposed and stayed sentence out of Langlade county. 
Defendant makes statements to the Court.  He wants to change this time.  He has a fiance who has never been in trouble.  He has distanced himself from the friends he had.  His son is going to be 17 years old and into football.  He wants to be with him with a clear head. 
Court addresses the defendant directly.  His child is a huge motivator.  Congratulates him on setting his goals and hopes he is able to do them.  Court is impressed that he paid the restitution.  

BY THE COURT:  
Count 1 - 
2 years prison with 1 year Initial Confinement followed by 1 year Extended Supervision. 
48 days credit. 
Eligible for the Substance Abuse program and Challenge Incarceration program. 
Copy of the Written Explanation of Determinate Sentence is provided to the defendant.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Kevin J. Husnick in court with attorney Erik John Mcfarland. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

9:11 a.m.  Court calls case and states the appearances. 

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
Count 1 - No contest

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty on Count 1.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty McFarland makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Defendant does not wish to make a statement prior to sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
Count 1 - 
Sentence withheld
*11 days jail credit if probation revoked
Placed on probation for 24 months - concurrent to any other probation
**Conditions of Probation:
*Maintain full-time employment.
*Participate in any counseling recommended by the agent.
*Write letter of apology to Walmart in Plover and provide to agent
*Not be on the premises of Walmart in Plover 
*Pay restitution in the amount of $1,033.29 - joint & several
*Provide true and accurate information to the District Attorney's Office regarding all other individual(s) involved in this theft
*Provide a DNA Sample
*Pay costs
*Pay DNA Surcharge
*Bond monies to be applied to restitution first and then costs

Defendant Kevin J. Husnick in court with attorney Erik John Mcfarland. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for November 30, 2015 at 08:30 am.
